title: Dingwall Canal Walk Route

images.title: Dingwall Canal by Mary and Angus Hogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Dingwall Canal was completed by 1819, to provide better access to the town, but was not a commercial success, and was abandoned in the 1880s after the arrival of the railways.

images.title: Les Shaw / The "Round Dingwall Walk" near the "mouth" of the Dingwall Canal
images.caption: The "Round Dingwall Walk" near the "mouth" of the Dingwall Canal. We are looking upstream in the picture and the tide is out. The path leads to Dingwall Junction where it crosses the railway. Only a narrow strip of land separates the north bank of the canal from the Cromarty Firth for this final half mile. Part of Dingwall is visible in the background.

images.title: Les Shaw / The Dingwall Canal enters the Cromarty Firth
images.caption: The Dingwall Canal enters the Cromarty Firth. The tide was out when this was taken. For the final half mile before it enters the sea, the canal is separated from the Cromarty Firth to the north by a narrow strip of land a few yards wide ending in the point shown near the middle of the image. Part of the Cromarty Bridge carrying the A9 is visible on the horizon to the left of the picture

images.title: Where the Dingwall Canal meets the sea by Julian Paren, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Where the Dingwall Canal meets the sea

images.title: Sculpture in Ferry Park, Dingwall by Mary and Angus Hogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sculpture in Ferry Park, Dingwall

images.title: The public park and picnic area at Ferry Point, Dingwall by Julian Paren, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The public park and picnic area at Ferry Point, Dingwall

images.title: St. James Street, Dingwall by Alpin Stewart, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St. James Street, Dingwall

images.title: High Street, Dingwall by Colin Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: High Street, Dingwall

description: This walk takes you along the Dingwall Canal in the town of Dingwall in the Highlands. It's a fine place for an easy stroll with some splendid coastal views at the end of the walk. The walk starts from Pefferside Park where there is a car parking area and views of the River Peffery which runs along the eastern side of the park. From here you can pick up trails heading east through the park to link up with the canal. Follow the canal east and it leads you to the Ferry Point park on the Cromarty Firth. In the park there's a picnic area and some wonderful views over the Firth to enjoy.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the west of the town there's the splendid Rogie Falls and Loch Achilty to explore. Also nearby is the village of Strathpeffer where you can enjoy a circular walk to the ancient rocks at the Touchstone Maze, the splendid Cat's Back Ridge and the picturesque Loch Ussie.

display_address: A862, Dingwall, Highland, Alba / Scotland, IV15 9PR, United Kingdom
